steps.title: Cut a hole
steps.content: Cut a hole in your material where you want the eyelet to go. This hole needs to be just big enough to push your eyelet through. If it is too big the eyelet will fall out. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Use a pad under the cloth to make a clean cut.
steps.content: Use a pad under the cloth to make a clean cut. The pad may be: a piece of hard leather ( see next photo ), an acrylic block like the cutting boards used in kitchens, a plastic floor tile or even a sheet of paper folded many times. Make sure you keep everything in place while making the hole !

steps.title: To cut the hole always put the pad under the "bad side" of the cloth.
steps.content: To cut the hole always put the pad under the "bad side" of the cloth. Exert strong pressure with the pliers or use a hammer to drive a hole with the eyelet punch.

steps.title: Push the eyelet through the hole you have made.
steps.content: Push the eyelet through the hole you have made. Do this from the right side of your material so the flat part of the eyelet is on the good side.

steps.title: Tuck any loose threads under the flat part of the eyelet so they are not visible.
steps.content: Tuck any loose threads under the flat part of the eyelet so they are not visible.

steps.title: Align your eyelet pliers.
steps.content: Align your eyelet pliers . [2] X Research source The flat (good) side of your eyelet should sit in the slightly curved side of the pliers, while the tube (bad) side of the eyelet should be aligned with the "pointed" side of the pliers. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Squeeze the pliers together.
steps.content: Squeeze the pliers together. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Take the pliers away and check that the eyelet is set as you want it.
steps.content: Take the pliers away and check that the eyelet is set as you want it. If it can be rotated in the material you will need to repeat the previous step with a little more force until it holds the material tightly.
